conclusion: The problem involves finding the turns ratio of an ideal transformer using given data: ammeter reading (1.4 A), voltmeter reading (10 V), and resistances on the secondary side (R1 = R2 = R3 = 50Ω).
The turns ratio of a transformer is defined as the ratio of the number of turns on the primary coil (n1) to the number of turns on the secondary coil (n2).

The diagram shows an ideal transformer with a primary coil connected to an AC power supply, an ammeter on the primary side, and three resistances (R1, R2, R3) connected in parallel on the secondary side along with a voltmeter.
The primary current is given as 1.4 A, and the secondary current is assumed to be the same (1.4 A) due to the ideal transformer assumption.
The primary voltage is expressed as V_primary = n1 × I_primary, and the secondary voltage is expressed as V_secondary = n2 × I_secondary.
Since the ammeter reads the same as the primary current, we have I_primary = I_secondary = 1.4 A.
The secondary voltage is calculated as V_secondary = n2 × I_secondary = n2 × 1.4 V.
The secondary voltage is also given by the voltmeter reading, V_secondary = 10 V.
Equating the two expressions for V_secondary, n2 × 1.4 V = 10 V.
Solving for n2, we get n2 = 10 V / 1.4 V ≈ 7.14.
The turns ratio of the primary and secondary coils of the transformer is approximately 7.14:1.
